text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with summer vegetable cavatelli
with fresh corn cream that's right not
only am i going to show you how to make
a very simple very delicious pasta I'm
also going to show you a possibly
game-changing technique for creating a
cream substitute using fresh sweet
summer corn
although game-changing might be a little
overstated let's go a genius and
revolutionary instead alright and to get
started of course we're going to need a
couple of years of corn and I'm using
some white corn from Brentwood
California and before we get started I
thought this was fascinating each of
these years of white corn had exactly
one golden kernel I bet that's caused by
something but anyway what we need to do
first is separate kernel from cob and I
generally like to use an extremely
dangerous method where I just shave it
off with a really sharp knife like this
barely avoiding cutting my knuckles but
because I got so much email the last
time I did that I thought I would show
you the safer method which is to invert
a ramekin like this and then hold the
cobs straight up and down like this
while we slice down in a much much safer
fashion and you can do this without the
ramekin but that holds it up a little
higher so our knife does not hit the
edges of the bowl which isn't really
great for your blade and not only do we
want to slice the kernels off but once
we do we want to use the back of the
knife like this and just kind of scrape
it down at an angle and that's going to
let us get the last of that sweet milky
goodness attached to the cob so don't
skip that step that's going to give us a
couple tablespoons of the best part of
the corn so we'll go ahead we'll do two
ears and once those clouds have bendy
kernel let's go ahead and transfer that
into a blender to which we'll add some
chicken broth or stock and I generally
like to do one cup of liquid per ear of
corn so I'm going to pour in two cups
and we'll head over to the blender and
blend this on high for a couple minutes
until completely smooth and then once
that's been accomplished we can pretty
much use this as is but because I like
to add steps and wash extra dishes I'm
going to go ahead and pass mine through
a fine strainer that's going to allow
all that beautiful sweet creamy goodness
to go through and the only thing we're
going to be left with is the toughest
most fibrous remnants so that is an
optional step but for me totally worth
the extra couple minutes
because you do get a silkier nicer
product and as soon as that's trained
what we're left with is what I'm calling
fresh sweet corn cream I know it kind of
looks more like corn milk but believe it
or not we can use this in any pasta that
calls for cream and it works pretty much
just about the same so that's done
and we'll just set that aside and move
on to the actual pasta so when a pan set
over medium heat into which I put a
little bit of olive oil I'm going to add
about 3 or 4 ounces of pancetta and
we're going to cook that pretty well
done
not quite crisp and yes you can
definitely just bacon here the only
difference between pancetta and bacon is
pancetta is not smoked so it just
depends on what you're going for here
but like I said we're going to cook that
on medium until pretty well done which
is going to take a few minutes so while
waiting for that you can go ahead and
pull the rest of your ingredients
together and thanks to a trip to farmers
market yesterday I'm going to do some
diced green zucchini some red bell
pepper and some unbelievably sweet and
incredibly tiny cherry tomatoes that I
cut in half and then of course we have
our dried pasta which is you already
heard we're using cavatelli and I'm not
exactly sure what that means in Italian
but based on the shape it probably is
slang for I don't know canoe maybe canoe
but anyway it doesn't matter the point
is while your pancetta is cooking we can
go ahead and get the rest of our
ingredients together so we'll head back
over the stove where as you can see our
pancetta is just about perfect but
before we add our veggies I do want to
remove a little bit of this fat and for
me the best way to do this is just with
a wadded up piece of paper towel all
right I find this very fast very easy
and virtually mess-free and we don't
have to get all of it we can leave a
little bit in there and then once that's
been accomplished we'll go ahead and add
our red pepper as well as our diced
zucchini or of course whatever veggies
you're using will also want to do a big
pinch of salt and we'll give that a stir
maybe we'll bump our heat up to
medium-high but you be the judge and
what we'll do is we'll saute that for
about 3 or 4 minutes just until that
zucchini starts to soften up ok we don't
want it mushy we just want to take that
raw edge off because this is going to
cook for a few more minutes in the sauce
and then what we're going to do this
point is turn off the heat I'm going to
go ahead and toss in a pinch of cayenne
and a little bit of freshly ground black
pepper and we'll give that a stir and
that pan is pretty much ready for the
pasta which ideally
you've time to finish cooking right
about this point but you don't have to
that's why we just turn the heat off all
right our pan of veggies can just sit
there for six or seven minutes while we
wait so as usual we'll boil our pasta in
some salted water and I will recommend
doing it like a minute under whatever
the box says because it will get cooked
a little more as we finish this dish off
and once our pasta is cooked we will add
it to our pan and make sure you're
draining it pretty good we don't want a
lot of water in this along with about a
cup and a half of our corn cream and
we'll turn our heat back on to
medium-high and then basically all we
have to do is wait for this to heat
through and thicken up a little bit
because of the starchiness in that corn
which if I'm not mistaken is very
similar to corn starch as this comes
back up to temperature and start
simmering you're going to notice that
thicken up nicely almost as if we were
reducing cream it's going to thicken up
and it should coat that pasta
beautifully so at this point we're going
to turn off the heat and add the last
few ingredients so we'll toss in our
sliced cherry tomatoes as well as some
fresh herb I'm gonna go with the Italian
parsley and basil then we'll also do a
little grating of some real parmesan
parmigiano-reggiano it's expensive but
we're only going to use about 25 cents
worth and we'll stir that all together
and that's pretty much it except for of
course the most important step taste for
seasoning so of course that's what I did
and ended up adding a little more salt
so be sure to check your the melly-mel
of your Cabot L and once that is
seasoned to perfection we can plate up
so I'm gonna spoon that into a pasta
bowl and quite possibly garnished with a
little extra cheese and maybe another
pinch of herb and that's simple but
beautiful summer vegetable cavatelli is
done sure you can do this exact same
recipe with just regular cream but not
only does the corn work beautifully
texture wise it also tastes like
delicious sweet corn so I really do love
this technique and in this particular
dish that sweetness really works so well
because it's playing off the acidity
from the tomatoes as well as pairing
perfectly with those fresh vegetables
and as far as the pancetta goes you know
what I should use bacon and hindsight
that smokiness would have been perfect
with this but despite that still very
very good but anyway that's it I don't
want to make too much of a simple pasta
dish but I do sort of
make a big deal about that corn cream so
whether you're lactose intolerance or
you're just running out of things to do
with fresh corn either way I really do
hope you give this a try soon so head
over to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
